deliberation: I checked whether the divorce and sale language might be literal. In context it is clearly figurative: Israel/Zion is cast as a wife/mother divorced and children sold to creditors, to depict exile and judgment. These are two distinct but related metaphors.

instances.english_text: the bill of divorce of your mother whom I dismissed
target: Israel/Zion’s covenant status and experience of being sent away (exile)
vehicle: a wife-mother who receives a bill of divorce and is sent away by her husband
marital divorce procedure
human family/social-legal life
ground: formal severing of a relationship and expulsion from the household
relational rupture and legal separation
social/legal realities of rejection
posture: negative portrayal of Israel’s condition as like a repudiated wife, while denying that God issued such a ‘document’
instances.explanation: Israel/Zion is personified as a mother-wife who would have a divorce document; the image of divorce is used metaphorically for the broken covenant and exile.

instances.hebrew_text: אוֹ מִי מִנּוֹשַׁי אֲשֶׁר־מָכַרְתִּי אֶתְכֶם לוֹ ... הֵן בַּעֲוֺנֹתֵיכֶם נִמְכַּרְתֶּם
instances.english_text: And which of My creditors was it to whom I sold you off? … You were only sold off for your sins
target: Israel’s loss of freedom and subjugation to foreign powers because of sin
vehicle: children being sold to a creditor to satisfy a debt
debt-slavery and commercial sale of persons
economic/legal life
ground: being transferred into another’s control as a consequence of incurred obligation
loss of freedom due to an owed debt
social/economic causality
posture: underscores that Israel’s bondage arises from its own iniquities, not from God’s financial ‘obligations’
instances.explanation: Being ‘sold’ to a creditor is a metaphor for Israel’s exile and servitude; ‘creditors’ stands metonymically for the foreign powers to whom Israel has been delivered.

deliberation: I looked at the questions about God’s ‘arm’ and the description of drying up the sea and rivers. The ‘short arm’ is a conventional metaphor/idiom for lack of power (with metonymic use of ‘arm’). The drying of sea and rivers by a mere rebuke is vivid theophanic imagery, not everyday description, and functions as a metaphorical, partly hyperbolic display of effortless power over personified nature.

instances.hebrew_text: הֲקָצוֹר קָצְרָה יָדִי מִפְּדוּת וְאִם־אֵין־בִּי כֹחַ לְהַצִּיל
instances.english_text: Is my arm, then, too short to rescue, have I not the power to save?
target: YHWH’s ability to redeem and save Israel
vehicle: a human arm that is too short to reach and pull someone to safety
physical limb and its reach
human bodily experience
ground: limited reach implies inability to effect rescue
strength vs. weakness in terms of reach and power
abstract power conceptualized through bodily capacity
posture: denies any limitation in God’s saving power by ridiculing the idea that his ‘arm’ could be short
instances.explanation: God’s ‘arm’ stands metonymically for his power; speaking of it as ‘too short’ is an idiomatic metaphor for inadequacy, which the verse emphatically denies.

instances.hebrew_text: הֵן בְּגַעֲרָתִי אַחֲרִיב יָם אָשִׂים נְהָרוֹת מִדְבָּר תִּבְאַשׁ דְּגָתָם מֵאֵין מַיִם וְתָמֹת בַּצָּמָא
instances.english_text: With a mere rebuke I dry up the sea, and turn rivers into desert. Their fish stink from lack of water; they lie dead of thirst.
target: the scope and ease of God’s control over creation and history
vehicle: a spoken rebuke that causes the sea and rivers to dry up, killing the fish
speech as an agent that devastates nature
natural catastrophe imagery
ground: effortless, word-based power that can totally alter the environment
capacity for sudden, comprehensive destruction
power expressed through command over nature
posture: dramatically asserts God’s overwhelming power by picturing nature as obedient to his rebuke and utterly at his mercy
instances.explanation: God’s ‘rebuke’ is treated as a force that dries seas and rivers, with the sea and rivers effectively personified as responding to his voice. The vivid catastrophe functions as a hyperbolic metaphor for his unmatched power.

deliberation: I examined whether the language about clothing the heavens is literal or figurative. Skies do not literally wear clothing; the verse personifies the heavens as a mourner dressed in black sackcloth, a common prophetic metaphor for cosmic mourning or judgment.

instances.hebrew_text: אַלְבִּישׁ שָׁמַיִם קַדְרוּת וְשַׂק אָשִׂים כְּסוּתָם
instances.english_text: I clothe the skies in blackness and make their raiment sackcloth.
target: the cosmic dimension and severity of divine judgment or sorrow
state of creation under God’s judgment
vehicle: a person whose body is clothed in black, rough sackcloth
mourning attire
human social/religious practice
ground: dark clothing and sackcloth signal grief, distress, or mourning
visual darkness as an index of calamity
shared symbolism of darkness and rough garments
posture: presents the whole sky as if it were a mourning person to intensify the sense of catastrophe
instances.explanation: The heavens are personified as a figure being dressed; dressing them in blackness and sackcloth metaphorically depicts cosmic mourning/judgment.

deliberation: I considered the ‘tongue of those who are taught’ and ‘rousing the ear.’ The first can be fairly literal (a trained/educated tongue), but ‘rousing my ear’ is not a normal physical action; it metaphorically/idiomatically depicts God making the servant attentive and obedient, with ‘ear’ as a synecdoche for the whole person’s receptivity.

instances.hebrew_text: יָעִיר בַּבֹּקֶר בַּבֹּקֶר יָעִיר לִי אֹזֶן לִשְׁמֹעַ כַּלִּמּוּדִים
instances.english_text: Morning by morning [God] rouses me, rousing my ear to give heed like disciples.
target: the servant’s responsiveness and teachability toward God’s instruction
vehicle: an ear being awakened from sleep each morning like a disciple summoned to listen
waking a sleeper so he can listen and learn
daily human routine and apprenticeship
ground: moving from sleep/unresponsiveness to wakefulness and attentive listening
fresh, repeated readiness to hear instruction
transition from passivity to active reception
posture: presents the servant as an eager, divinely-awakened learner
instances.explanation: Ears do not literally ‘sleep’ and need to be ‘roused’; this idiomatic metaphor (with the ear as a synecdoche for the person) pictures God continually awakening the servant to attentive discipleship.

deliberation: I tested whether ‘opened my ears’ is bodily or figurative. In prophetic diction, opening the ear is a standard idiom for granting receptive obedience. Here it functions metaphorically for God enabling the servant to hear and obey.

instances.english_text: My Sovereign GOD opened my ears
target: the servant’s God-given capacity and willingness to obey
vehicle: physically opening a closed ear so that it can hear
removing a blockage from a sense organ
bodily action
ground: eliminating obstruction to perception results in clear hearing
making previously closed-off faculties responsive
enablement through removal of barriers
posture: attributes the servant’s obedience entirely to God’s enabling action
instances.explanation: The phrase ‘opened my ears’ is an idiomatic metaphor (with the ear as a synecdoche for the person’s willingness) for God granting understanding and submissive listening.

deliberation: I evaluated the descriptions of back, cheeks, hair, face, disgrace, and spittle. All of these can be taken as straightforward physical and social abuse without clear indication that they stand for something else. No distinct metaphor, simile, or other marked figurative device appears; it is vivid but essentially literal narrative of suffering.

The key candidate is ‘I have set my face like flint.’ This is an explicit simile (כ) and idiomatic metaphor: ‘face’ stands for resolve and ‘flint’ for extreme hardness. The rest of the verse (help, not disgraced, not shamed) can be read literally in the moral sense.

instances.english_text: Therefore I have set my face like flint
target: the servant’s inner resolve to persevere in obedience despite opposition
vehicle: a face compared to flint, a very hard stone
extremely hard material
physical/natural world
ground: hardness, unyielding resistance to pressure or blows
steadfastness and inability to be deflected
shared abstraction of firmness
posture: approving portrayal of unwavering obedience as something rock-hard
instances.explanation: The servant’s ‘face’ (a synecdoche for his determined stance) is likened to hard flint, an idiomatic simile conveying unbending resolve in the face of shame.

deliberation: I looked for legal imagery and found an extended courtroom metaphor: ‘my vindicator is near,’ ‘who contends with me?,’ ‘let us stand up together,’ ‘who is my adversary?,’ ‘let him approach me.’ This frames the servant’s conflict with opponents as a lawsuit with God as advocate/judge.

instances.hebrew_text: קָרוֹב מַצְדִּיקִי מִי־יָרִיב אִתִּי נַעַמְדָה יָּחַד מִי־בַעַל מִשְׁפָּטִי יִגַּשׁ אֵלָי
instances.english_text: My Vindicator is at hand—Who dares contend with me? Let us stand up together! Who would be my opponent? Let them approach me!
target: the servant’s dispute with his opponents and his confidence in God’s declaration of his innocence
vehicle: a formal courtroom scene with litigants, an advocate, and an opponent approaching for trial
legal contest (lawsuit)
judicial life in society
ground: a dispute decided by a recognized authority who declares someone ‘in the right’
need for an advocate and a judge to resolve accusations
forensic concepts of justification and condemnation
posture: frames the servant’s situation as a legal case in which God’s proximity guarantees acquittal
instances.explanation: God is depicted as ‘my Vindicator’ in a legal sense, and the contention with opponents is cast as a lawsuit, a courtroom metaphor for divine justification.

deliberation: Two distinct images appear: opponents ‘wear out like a garment’ and ‘the moth shall eat them.’ The first is a simile comparing their fate to decaying clothing; the second is a metaphor extending the garment imagery, where moths that eat cloth are used as an image for their destruction.

instances.english_text: They shall all wear out like a garment
target: the existence and power of the servant’s adversaries
vehicle: a garment that gradually becomes old and threadbare
decaying clothing
everyday household object
ground: inevitable, gradual decay leading to worthlessness
transience and impermanence
vulnerability to time and wear
posture: minimizes the lasting significance of the opponents by likening them to perishable clothing
instances.explanation: The adversaries are explicitly compared to a garment that wears out, highlighting their transience and fragility through a homely simile.

target: the ultimate ruin of the adversaries
vehicle: moths eating holes in fabric until it is destroyed
insect damage to cloth
natural/household process
ground: silent, often unseen action leading to utter ruin of something once useful
slow but inexorable destruction
fragility before small but destructive agents
posture: depicts their downfall as certain and thorough, even if not spectacular
rhetorical accent on inevitability of judgment
instances.explanation: Moths do not literally eat people; the image extends the garment metaphor so that the adversaries’ fate is like cloth being eaten through by moths—an exaggerated but vivid metaphor for total ruin.

deliberation: I examined ‘walking in darkness and having no light.’ No explicit comparison word is used, but the phrase is conventional metaphor/idiom: darkness stands for distress, confusion, or lack of guidance for someone who nevertheless trusts YHWH.

instances.english_text: though walking in darkness and having no light
target: the experience of a God-fearing person under trial, perplexity, or lack of visible guidance
vehicle: a traveler walking in physical darkness without any light source
journeying in the dark
physical environment and movement
ground: insecurity, inability to see the path, and heightened risk in darkness
uncertainty and vulnerability
lack of clear orientation
posture: acknowledges the reality of disorientation while directing such a person to trust in YHWH’s name
instances.explanation: ‘Walking in darkness’ is an idiomatic metaphor for living through times of confusion or affliction without clear guidance, contrasted with trusting in God.

deliberation: The fire imagery (‘kindlers of fire,’ ‘girding firebrands,’ ‘walk by the blaze of your fire’) is obviously not about literal torches the audience is carrying; it metaphorically depicts self-made guidance or schemes, and the imperative ‘walk in your fire’ has an ironic tone. ‘You shall lie down in pain’ then portrays the final outcome of these choices as a state of inescapable torment, likely also metaphorical rather than a literal posture.

instances.hebrew_text: כֻּלְּכֶם קֹדְחֵי אֵשׁ מְאַזְּרֵי זִיקוֹת לְכוּ בְּאוּר אֶשְׁכֶם וּבְזִיקוֹת בִּעַרְתֶּם
instances.english_text: But you are all kindlers of fire, girding on firebrands. Walk by the blaze of your fire, by the brands that you have lit!
target: the people’s self-generated schemes and false sources of guidance in defiance of God
human autonomy and misguided reliance on self-made ‘light’
vehicle: people who start their own fire, strap on firebrands, and walk by that fire’s light
kindling and carrying torches for one’s own illumination
everyday practice of making and using fire
ground: creating and trusting in a light of one’s own making instead of receiving light from another
self-reliant but ultimately dangerous guidance
independence that leads to harm
posture: ironically commands them to follow their own fire to highlight the folly and doom of such self-reliance
instances.explanation: ‘Kindlers of fire’ and ‘walk by the blaze of your fire’ are metaphors (and an ironic idiom) for people who construct and rely on their own guidance or security instead of God’s; the imperative is biting irony, not genuine exhortation.

instances.english_text: This has come to you from My hand: You shall lie down in pain.
target: the people’s final experience of divine judgment as a settled, inescapable state
vehicle: lying down in a place characterized by pain or torment
a person forced to lie down in suffering instead of rest
bodily posture associated with rest or death
ground: lying down implies cessation of activity and vulnerability; combined with ‘pain’ it suggests helpless, enduring affliction
finality and passivity in suffering
rest imagery inverted into torment
posture: threatens an imposed, God-sent condition of unrelieved distress as the result of their self-chosen ‘fire’
instances.explanation: ‘Lie down in pain’ is an idiomatic metaphor for entering a final, helpless state of torment under God’s hand, playing off normal ‘lying down’ as rest or sleep.
